Award.AwardTitle: Resolving CO2 System Seasonality in the West Antarctic Peninsula with Autonomous Observations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Interest in the reduced alkalinity of high latitude waters under conditions of enhanced CO2 uptake from the atmosphere have been the impetus of numerous recent studies of bio-stressors in the polar marine environment. The project seeks to improve our understanding of the variance of coastal Southern Ocean carbonate species (CO2 system), its diurnal and inter-annual variability, by acquiring autonomous, high frequency observations from an Antarctic coastal mooring(s).

A moored observing system co-located within the existing Palmer LTER array will measure pH, CO2 partial pressure, temperature, salinity and dissolved oxygen with 3-hour frequency in this region of the West Antarctic Peninsula continental shelf. Such observations will help estimate the dominant physical and biological controls on the seasonal variations in the CO2 system in coastal Antarctic waters, including the sign, seasonality and the flux of the net annual air-sea exchange of carbon dioxide. The Palmer LTER site is experiencing rapid ecological change in the West Antarctic Peninsula, a region that is warming at rates faster than any other region of coastal Antarctica.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The western Antarctic Peninsula is experiencing some of the most rapid climate change of any location on the planet. Air and ocean temperatures are warming, seasonal sea-ice cover is disappearing, and glaciers and ice-sheets are melting. The climate change effects on the coastal marine ecosystem are already apparent, with shifts occurring across the food web from plankton up to penguins and whales. A second, less well understood concern for polar oceans comes from human carbon emissions, primarily the result of fossil fuel combustion, that raise atmosphere carbon dioxide levels. Some of the excess carbon dioxide from the atmosphere enters the surface ocean via gas exchange causing wholesale changes in seawater acid-base chemistry, typically termed ocean acidification. More acidic conditions can damage some types of plankton and other marine life that build shells from calcium carbonate minerals.

Gradual acidification of the surface ocean has been observed in the sub-tropics and temperate latitudes, but a clear ocean acidification signal has been difficult to detect for the western Antarctic Peninsula. Harsh conditions limit ship-based sampling, especially in the winter. Large seasonal and year to year physical and biological variations obscure any longer-term trend. To address this critical gap in ocean observations, this project deployed advanced chemical sensors that measure the amount carbon dioxide on seawater on a mooring on the Antarctic continental shelf. The chemical instrument package was placed below the actual ocean surface to avoid damage from winter sea-ice and passing icebergs. The mooring measurements provided the first full record over the annual cycle of ocean carbon dioxide levels and seawater acid-base chemistry for the western Antarctic.

The mooring data showed that Antarctic surface waters on the shelf undergo a large seasonal variation from winter to summer. During the winter, surface ocean carbon dioxide levels are elevated by the physical resupply of carbon rich sub-surface waters brought upward by strong vertical mixing caused by ocean cooling and sea-ice formation. Conversely in the summer, surface carbon dioxide levels are low, reduced by biological uptake during phytoplankton photosynthesis. Because of the low surface water carbon dioxide levels during the ice-free summer, there is also a net gas transfer of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere into the ocean. 

The mooring data reinforces and extends recent results derived from an analysis of historical ship-based carbon dioxide data collected on the Antarctic shelf, mostly during the summer. The new estimate for the seasonal biological carbon drawdown provides an independent, upper limit on a key parameter of the shelf marine ecosystem, the annual net community production of organic matter, that can help guide studies of food-web dynamics, biogeochemistry and satellite-based algorithms of biological productivity and carbon storage. The mooring-based ocean carbon data record also provides a unique coastal end-member that complements the extensive work ongoing for the open-ocean carbon system of the Southern Ocean using autonomous biogeochemical floats, which typically do not stray onto the continental shelf.
